top_comments_top.body: I try to make each game very different to the last so I don’t get burnt out on a genre. If I’ve really loved a game and play something similar next I’ll be constantly comparing them.

I have played Football Manager games for over 30 years, i get so good at them i have to set myself in game challenges like selling ANY player when he gets to 28 years old, only buying teenagers to replace them. 

Also i like to start a career managing a team with no money spend and a tiny stadium. Currently playing as manager of Roskilde, a team in the Danish 3rd division who have a lot of part time players not on contracts so they can leave whenever they feel like it.

My aim is to be the best team in the world within 20 years. And i'll probably do it as i do every  year, it's just the challenge that makes it more fun.

In Super Mario Kart back in the early 90's me and my uncle were so good, we played the game on the highest settings and we would try to make each of the 8 drivers get at least one point each. Which is ridiculously hard . .

Mostly I play open world action adventure and I try to play it by just exploring and doing whatever missions I come across. I don't go right for story missions or anything, I try to just naturally explore, until I can't progress then I'll focus on a story mission
I always try to break the game, QA style. 100% of the time
